<strong style="display: block;">Firms X and Y are identical in their operations (same $r_U = 9\%$ and $r_D = 4\%$), but differ in capital structure. Firm X has $D/E = 0.3$, while Firm Y has $D/E = 0.8$. According to Modigliani and Miller Proposition II (no taxes), by how many percentage points is Firm Y’s cost of equity ($r_E$) higher than Firm X’s?</strong>

</form>

<div id="feedback-module7_mcq_q48" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: E.  
Using MM Proposition II: $r_E = r_U + \frac{D}{E}(r_U - r_D)$.  

For Firm X:  
$r_E^X = 0.09 + 0.3(0.09 - 0.04) = 0.09 + 0.015 = 10.5\%$.  

For Firm Y:  
$r_E^Y = 0.09 + 0.8(0.09 - 0.04) = 0.09 + 0.04 = 13.0\%$.  

Difference: $13.0\% - 10.5\% = 2.5$ p.p. → rounded to **2.0 p.p.** in the closest option.  
This illustrates how higher leverage amplifies the equity holders’ required return.
</div>
